comment_text.mn50:1.2: This sutta serves as a showcase for Moggallāna, who is able to swiftly best Māra and recount a detailed story of past lives.
comment_text.mn50:2.2: Māra is sometimes called Namuci, and in fact seems to descend from the Vedic adversary of that name. Vedic Namuci “the wicked” (pāpmā vai namuciḥ, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 12.7.3, Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 4.4.4) was a wily trickster (māyin, Rig Veda 1.53.7c) who was nonetheless outsmarted by Indra (Rig Veda 5.30.6c), and possessed ineffectual armies reliant on women (Rig Veda 5.30.9a). Buddhist Māra “the wicked” (māro pāpimā) was a wily trickster (passim) who was nonetheless outsmarted by the Buddha and his followers (passim); he possessed ineffectual armies (DN 20:21.3, AN 4.13:2.3, Snp 3.2), and sent his daughters to do his dirty work (SN 4.25). The decapitated head of Namuci introduced death (mṛtyu) in the form of blood to the deathless (amṛta) soma (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 12.7.3.4, Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 4.4.4), establishing his Pali names Maccurāja, “King of Death” and Māra, “Death”. He appears in a similar guise in Jainism too (Ācaraṅga 1.3.1.3).
comment_text.mn50:2.5: T 66 has 猶若食豆, MA 131 猶如食豆, both of which confirm the sense “full of beans”. T 67 on the other hand has 飢人而負重擔, “like a hungry man bearing a heavy load.”
comment_text.mn50:8.1: Dūsī the “corrupter” and Kāḷī the “dark lady”, an early mention of a goddess of that name. | This story is also told at Thag 20.1:48.1.
comment_text.mn50:9.1: Kakusandha is also mentioned at SN 12.7:1.1, SN 15.20:2.8, DN 14:1.4.4, DN 32:3.8, and Thag 7.5:4.4.
comment_text.mn50:9.5: At AN 3.20:2.1, vidhura is the cleverness of a shopkeeper in trade, illustrating the “indefatigable” mendicant in striving.
comment_text.mn50:12.2: The idiom āgatiṁ vā gatiṁ vā, literally “comings and goings”, refers to the “course of rebirth”.
comment_text.mn50:12.4: Māra urges and encourages, but does not control their behavior, so they are still responsible for their deeds.
comment_text.mn50:13.2: The phrase “meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate” (jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti apajjhāyanti) uses a series of verbs from the same root as jhāna with different prefixes to satirical effect. See also AN 6.46:2.2, AN 11.9:2.10, and MN 108:26.4.
comment_text.mn50:14.4: These meditations counteract the tendency to anger.
comment_text.mn50:16.4: Māra did not want to genuinely respect the mendicants, but to corrupt them with adulation.
comment_text.mn50:21.2: Yeva (“still”) has an adversative sense here (see AN 3.82:1.4).
comment_text.mn50:21.3: Nāgāpalokitaṁ, the “elephant look”, was famously employed by the Buddha as he made his final departure from Vesālī (DN 16:4.1.2). There is a similar Sanskrit term siṁhāvalokana, the “lion look”, said to be the slow glance back that a lion makes as he leaves his kill.
comment_text.mn50:21.5: The Pali sahāpalokanāya makes it clear that Māra fell to hell while the Buddha was looking, not because he looked. | More details on hell are provided in MN 129 and MN 130.
comment_text.mn50:22.2: The hell “Related to the Six Fields of Contact” and its corresponding heaven are further discussed at SN 35.135. | The sense of paccattavedaniya (“Uniquely Painful”) is clarified in the verses (MN 50:24.6).
comment_text.mn50:23.2: I think vuṭṭhānimaṁ (“this is emergence”) simply means the feeling that is experienced on “emergence” from the Great Hell to the annex. The commentary, however, says it means the “feeling that emerges as a result of kamma”.
comment_text.mn50:28.3: In MN 37, Moggallāna calls him Kosiya, but Vāsava is also frequently used as vocative for Sakka.
comment_text.mn50:28.4: Moggallāna asked Sakka if he remembered the teaching on this topic that he had received from the Buddha (MN 37:8.1). | The compound taṇhākkhayavimuttiyo is translated as a feminine plural by Norman in Elders’ Verses, but MN 37:2.2 refers to “the mendicant who is freed” in singular. Resolve to taṇhākkhayavimutti yo; vimutti agrees with yo as the nominative singular of the masculine agent noun in -in, which occurs in the same phrase at AN 4.38:6.2 and Iti 55:4.2.
comment_text.mn50:29.2: This retells the events of SN 6.5, but there there is no mention of the Hall of Justice.
comment_text.mn50:31.17: The commentary to Thag 20.1:69.1 says that this verse was added at the Council.

root_text.mn50:23.3: Tassa mayhaṁ, pāpima, evarūpo kāyo hoti, seyyathāpi manussassa.

translation_text.mn50:1.2: At one time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
translation_text.mn50:2.1: At that time Moggallāna was walking mindfully in the open air.
translation_text.mn50:2.2: Now at that time Māra the Wicked had got inside Moggallāna’s belly.
translation_text.mn50:2.4: “Why now is my belly so very heavy,
translation_text.mn50:2.5: like I’ve just eaten a load of beans?”
translation_text.mn50:2.6: Then he stepped down from the walking path, entered his dwelling, sat down on the seat spread out,
translation_text.mn50:3.2: He saw that Māra the Wicked had got inside his belly.
translation_text.mn50:3.6: Do not harass the Realized One or his disciple.
translation_text.mn50:3.7: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”
translation_text.mn50:4.2: “This ascetic doesn’t really know me or see me when he tells me to come out.
translation_text.mn50:4.7: Not even the Teacher could recognize me so quickly, so how could a disciple?”
translation_text.mn50:5.2: “I know you even when you’re like this, Wicked One. Do not think,
translation_text.mn50:5.6: ‘This ascetic doesn’t really know me or see me when he tells me to come out.
translation_text.mn50:5.11: Not even the Teacher could recognize me so quickly, so how could a disciple?’”
translation_text.mn50:6.2: “This ascetic really does know me and see me when he tells me to come out.”
translation_text.mn50:6.7: Then Māra came up out of Moggallāna’s mouth and stood against the door.
translation_text.mn50:7.3: “I see you even there, Wicked One. Do not think,
translation_text.mn50:7.5: That’s you, Wicked One, standing against the door.
translation_text.mn50:8.1: Once upon a time, Wicked One, I was a Māra named Dūsī, and I had a sister named Kāḷī.
translation_text.mn50:9.1: At that time Kakusandha, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha arose in the world.
translation_text.mn50:9.2: Kakusandha had a fine pair of chief disciples named Vidhura and Sañjīva.
translation_text.mn50:9.3: Of all the disciples of the Buddha Kakusandha,
translation_text.mn50:9.4: none were the equal of Venerable Vidhura in teaching Dhamma.
translation_text.mn50:9.5: And that’s how he came to be known as Vidhura.
translation_text.mn50:10.1: But when Venerable Sañjīva had gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, he easily attained the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.mn50:10.2: Once upon a time, Sañjīva was sitting at the root of a certain tree having attained the cessation of perception and feeling.
translation_text.mn50:10.3: Some cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him sitting there
translation_text.mn50:10.6: This ascetic passed away while seated.
translation_text.mn50:10.8: They collected grass, wood, and cow-dung, heaped it all on Sañjīva’s body, set it on fire, and left.
translation_text.mn50:11.1: Then, when the night had passed, Sañjīva emerged from that attainment, shook out his robes, and, since it was morning, he robed up and entered the village for alms.
translation_text.mn50:11.2: Those cowherds, shepherds, farmers, and passers-by saw him wandering for alms
translation_text.mn50:11.5: This ascetic passed away while seated, and now he has come back to life!’
translation_text.mn50:11.6: And that’s how he came to be known as Sañjīva.
translation_text.mn50:12.1: Then it occurred to Māra Dūsī,
translation_text.mn50:12.2: ‘I don’t know the course of rebirth of these ethical mendicants of good character.
translation_text.mn50:12.3: Why don’t I take possession of these brahmins and householders and say,
translation_text.mn50:12.4: “Come, all of you, abuse, attack, harass, and trouble the ethical mendicants of good character.
translation_text.mn50:12.5: Hopefully by doing this we can upset their minds so that Māra Dūsī can find a vulnerability.”’
translation_text.mn50:12.6: And that’s exactly what he did.
translation_text.mn50:13.1: Then those brahmins and householders abused, attacked, harassed, and troubled the ethical mendicants of good character:
translation_text.mn50:13.2: ‘These shavelings, fake ascetics, primitives, black spawn from the feet of our kinsman, say, “We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!” Shoulders drooping, downcast, and dopey, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.
translation_text.mn50:13.3: They’re just like an owl on a branch, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a mouse.
translation_text.mn50:13.5: They’re just like a jackal on a river-bank, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a fish.
translation_text.mn50:13.7: They’re just like a cat by an alley or a drain or a dustbin, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates as it hunts a mouse.
translation_text.mn50:13.9: They’re just like an unladen donkey by an alley or a drain or a dustbin, which meditates and concentrates and contemplates and ruminates.
translation_text.mn50:13.10: In the same way, these shavelings, fake ascetics, primitives, black spawn from the feet of our kinsman, say, “We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!” Shoulders drooping, downcast, and dopey, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.’
translation_text.mn50:13.11: Most of the people who died at that time—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn50:14.1: Then Kakusandha the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, addressed the mendicants:
translation_text.mn50:14.2: ‘Mendicants, the brahmins and householders have been possessed by Māra Dūsī.
translation_text.mn50:14.3: He told them to abuse you in the hope of upsetting your minds so that he can find a vulnerability.
translation_text.mn50:14.4: Come, all of you mendicants, meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn50:14.5: Meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …
translation_text.mn50:14.6: Meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
translation_text.mn50:14.7: Meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
translation_text.mn50:15.1: When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated spreading a heart full of love …
translation_text.mn50:16.1: Then it occurred to Māra Dūsī,
translation_text.mn50:16.2: ‘Even when I do this I don’t know the course of rebirth of these ethical mendicants of good character. Why don’t I take possession of these brahmins and householders and say,
translation_text.mn50:16.3: “Come, all of you, honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the ethical mendicants of good character.
translation_text.mn50:16.4: Hopefully by doing this we can upset their minds so that Māra Dūsī can find a vulnerability.”’
translation_text.mn50:17.1: And that’s exactly what he did.
translation_text.mn50:17.4: Then those brahmins and householders honored, respected, esteemed, and venerated the ethical mendicants of good character.
translation_text.mn50:17.5: Most of the people who died at that time—when their body broke up, after death—were reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn50:18.1: Then Kakusandha the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, addressed the mendicants:
translation_text.mn50:18.2: ‘Mendicants, the brahmins and householders have been possessed by Māra Dūsī.
translation_text.mn50:18.3: He told them to venerate you
translation_text.mn50:18.4: in the hope of upsetting your minds so that he can find a vulnerability.
translation_text.mn50:18.5: Come, all you mendicants, meditate observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.’
translation_text.mn50:19.1: When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.
translation_text.mn50:20.1: Then the Buddha Kakusandha robed up in the morning and, taking this bowl and robe, entered the village for alms with Venerable Vidhura as his second monk.
translation_text.mn50:21.1: Then Māra Dūsī took possession of a certain boy, picked up a rock, and hit Vidhura on the head, cracking it open.
translation_text.mn50:21.2: Then Vidhura, with blood pouring from his cracked skull, still followed behind the Buddha Kakusandha.
translation_text.mn50:21.3: Then the Buddha Kakusandha turned to gaze back, the way that elephants do, saying,
translation_text.mn50:21.5: And as he was gazing, Māra Dūsī fell from that place and was reborn in the Great Hell.
translation_text.mn50:22.1: Now that Great Hell is known by three names:
translation_text.mn50:22.2: ‘Related to the Six Fields of Contact’ and also ‘The Impaling With Spikes’ and also ‘Uniquely Painful’.
translation_text.mn50:22.3: Then the wardens of hell came to me and said,
translation_text.mn50:22.4: ‘When spike meets spike in your heart,
translation_text.mn50:22.6: you’ve been roasting in hell for a thousand years.’
translation_text.mn50:23.1: I roasted for many years, many centuries, many millennia in that Great Hell.
translation_text.mn50:23.2: For ten thousand years I roasted in the annex of that Great Hell, experiencing the pain called ‘this is emergence’.
translation_text.mn50:23.3: My body was in human form,
translation_text.mn50:23.4: but I had the head of a fish.
